messages.content: Where is Algeria located?
Northern Africa, bordering the Mediterranean Sea, between Morocco and Tunisia
What are the geographic coordinates of Algeria?
What map region is Algeria in?
Africa
How much land area does Algeria have?
2,381,740 square kilometers
How much water area does Algeria have?
0 square kilometers
How does the area of Algeria compare to other places?
slightly less than 3.5 times the size of Texas
What is the total length of Algeria's land boundaries?
6,734 kilometers
What is the coastline length of Algeria?
998 kilometers
How much land is irrigated in Algeria?
13,819 square kilometers (2019)
What is the population of Algeria?
How is the population distributed in Algeria?
the vast majority of the populace is found in the extreme northern part of the country along the Mediterranean Coast
What percent of Algeria's population is urban?
75.3% of total population (2023)
What is the rate of urbanization in Algeria?
1.99% annual rate of change (2020-25 est.)
What ethnic groups are found in Algeria?
Arab-Amazigh 99%, European less than 1%
What is the capital of Algeria?
Algiers
What are the geographic coordinates of Algeria's capital?
What are the land boundaries of Algeria?

Algeria has 6,734 kilometers of land boundaries, including borders with Libya (989 kilometers), Mali (1,359 kilometers), Mauritania (460 kilometers), Morocco (1,941 kilometers), Niger (951 kilometers), and Tunisia (1,034 kilometers).
What are Algeria's maritime claims?
Algeria claims a territorial sea of 12 nautical miles, a contiguous zone of 24 nautical miles, and an exclusive fishing zone of 32 to 52 nautical miles.
What is the climate of Algeria?

Algeria has an arid to semiarid climate, with mild, wet winters and hot, dry summers along the coast. The high plateau is drier with cold winters and hot summers, and the sirocco is a hot, dust-laden wind that is especially common in summer.
What is the terrain of Algeria like?
Algeria is mostly high plateau and desert, with the Atlas Mountains in the far north and the Hoggar Mountains in the south. It also has a narrow, discontinuous coastal plain.
What natural resources does Algeria have?
Algeria’s natural resources include petroleum, natural gas, iron ore, phosphates, uranium, lead, and zinc.
What is the land use in Algeria?

In Algeria, 17.4% of the land is used for agriculture, including 3.2% arable land, 0.4% permanent crops, and 13.8% permanent pasture (2023 est.). Forest accounts for 0.7% and other land uses make up 81.9% (2023 est.).
What natural hazards affect Algeria?
Algeria is subject to severe earthquakes in mountainous areas, as well as mudslides and floods during the rainy season. Droughts also occur.
What are the major environmental issues in Algeria?

Major environmental issues in Algeria include air pollution in major cities, soil erosion from overgrazing and poor farming practices, and desertification. Water pollution from sewage and industrial wastes and inadequate potable water are also problems.
What languages are spoken in Algeria?

Languages in Algeria include Arabic (official), Tamazight (official), and French as a widely used lingua franca. Tamazight includes dialects such as Kabyle (Taqbaylit), Shawiya (Tacawit), Mzab, and Tuareg (Tamahaq).
What religions are practiced in Algeria?

Algeria is predominantly Muslim (official; mostly Sunni) at about 99%, with other religions including Christian, Jewish, Ahmadi Muslim, Shia Muslim, and Ibadi Muslim making up less than 1% (2012 est.).
What is the median age in Algeria?
The median age in Algeria is 29.1 years (2024 est.).
Where is Angola located?
Southern Africa, bordering the South Atlantic Ocean, between Namibia and Democratic Republic of the Congo
What are the geographic coordinates of Angola?
What map region is Angola in?
Africa
How much land area does Angola have?
1,246,700 square kilometers
How much water area does Angola have?
0 square kilometers
What is the total length of Angola's land boundaries?
5,369 kilometers
What is the coastline length of Angola?
1,600 kilometers
What is the terrain of Angola like?
narrow coastal plain rises abruptly to vast interior plateau
How much land is irrigated in Angola?
860 square kilometers (2014)
What natural hazards affect Angola?
locally heavy rainfall causes periodic flooding on the plateau
What is the population of Angola?
What percent of Angola's population is urban?
68.7% of total population (2023)
What is the rate of urbanization in Angola?
4.04% annual rate of change (2020-25 est.)
What is the capital of Angola?
Luanda
What are the geographic coordinates of Angola's capital?
How does the area of Angola compare to other places?
about eight times the size of Georgia; slightly less than twice the size of Texas
What are the land boundaries of Angola?

Angola has 5,369 kilometers of land boundaries, including borders with the Democratic Republic of the Congo (2,646 kilometers, including 225 kilometers around Cabinda Province), the Republic of the Congo (231 kilometers), Namibia (1,427 kilometers), and Zambia (1,065 kilometers).
What are Angola's maritime claims?
Angola claims a territorial sea of 12 nautical miles, a contiguous zone of 24 nautical miles, and an exclusive economic zone of 200 nautical miles.
What is the climate of Angola?
Angola is semiarid in the south and along the coast to Luanda, while the north has a cool, dry season from May to October and a hot, rainy season from November to April.
What natural resources does Angola have?
Angola’s natural resources include petroleum, diamonds, iron ore, phosphates, copper, feldspar, gold, bauxite, and uranium.
What is the land use in Angola?

In Angola, 36.9% of the land is used for agriculture, including 4.3% arable land, 0.3% permanent crops, and 32.4% permanent pasture (2023 est.). Forest accounts for 51.6% and other land uses make up 11.5% (2023 est.).
What are the major environmental issues in Angola?

Major environmental issues in Angola include overuse of pastures leading to soil erosion, desertification, and deforestation of tropical rainforest. Loss of biodiversity, water pollution and siltation from soil erosion, and inadequate potable water supplies are also concerns.
How is the population distributed in Angola?
most people live in the western half of the country; urban areas account for the highest concentrations of people, particularly the capital of Luanda
What languages are spoken in Angola?
Languages in Angola include Portuguese (official) and indigenous languages such as Umbundu, Kikongo, Kimbundu, Chokwe, Nhaneca, Nganguela, Fiote, Kwanhama, Muhumbi, and Luvale (2014 est.).
What religions are practiced in Angola?
Roman Catholic 41.1%, Protestant 38.1%, other 8.6%, none 12.3% (2014 est.)
What ethnic groups are found in Angola?
Ovimbundu 37%, Kimbundu 25%, Bakongo 13%, Mestico (mixed European and native African) 2%, European 1%, other 22%
What is the median age in Angola?
The median age in Angola is 16.3 years (2024 est.).
Where is Botswana located?
Southern Africa, north of South Africa
What are the geographic coordinates of Botswana?
What map region is Botswana in?
Africa
How much land area does Botswana have?
566,730 square kilometers
How much water area does Botswana have?
15,000 square kilometers
What is the total length of Botswana's land boundaries?
4,347.15 kilometers
What is the coastline length of Botswana?
0 kilometers 0 kilometers as the country is landlocked.
What are Botswana's maritime claims?
This country has no maritime claims because it is a landlocked country.
How much land is irrigated in Botswana?
25 square kilometers (2014)
What is the population of Botswana?
What percent of Botswana's population is urban?
72.9% of total population (2023)
What is the rate of urbanization in Botswana?
2.47% annual rate of change (2020-25 est.)
What is the capital of Botswana?
Gaborone
What are the geographic coordinates of Botswana's capital?
How does the area of Botswana compare to other places?
slightly smaller than Texas; almost four times the size of Illinois
What are the land boundaries of Botswana?
Botswana has 4,347.15 kilometers of land boundaries, including borders with Namibia (1,544 kilometers), South Africa (1,969 kilometers), Zambia (0.15 kilometers), and Zimbabwe (834 kilometers).
What is the climate of Botswana?
semiarid; warm winters and hot summers
What is the terrain of Botswana like?
predominantly flat to gently rolling tableland; Kalahari Desert in southwest
What natural resources does Botswana have?
Botswana’s natural resources include diamonds, copper, nickel, salt, soda ash, potash, coal, iron ore, and silver.
What is the land use in Botswana?

In Botswana, 45.6% of the land is used for agriculture, including 0.5% arable land, 0% permanent crops, and 45.2% permanent pasture (2023 est.). Forest accounts for 27.8% and other land uses make up 26.6% (2023 est.).
What natural hazards affect Botswana?
Botswana experiences periodic droughts, and seasonal August winds can blow sand and dust across the country and obscure visibility.
What are the major environmental issues in Botswana?
overgrazing; desertification; limited freshwater resources; air pollution
How is the population distributed in Botswana?

the population is primarily concentrated in the east, with a focus in and around the capital of Gaborone and the eastern city of Francistown; population density remains low in other areas in the country, especially in the Kalahari Desert to the west.
What languages are spoken in Botswana?
Languages in Botswana include Setswana and English (official), along with Sekalanga, Shekgalagadi, Zezuru/Shona, Sesarwa, Sembukushu, and Ndebele (2011 est.).
What religions are practiced in Botswana?
Christian 79.1%, Badimo 4.1%, other 1.4% (includes Baha'i, Hindu, Muslim, Rastafarian), none 15.2%, unspecified 0.3% (2011 est.)
What ethnic groups are found in Botswana?
Tswana (or Setswana) 79%, Kalanga 11%, Basarwa 3%, other, including Kgalagadi and people of European ancestry 7%
What is the median age in Botswana?
The median age in Botswana is 27.1 years (2024 est.).
Where is Benin located?
Western Africa, bordering the Bight of Benin, between Nigeria and Togo
What are the geographic coordinates of Benin?
What map region is Benin in?
Africa
How much land area does Benin have?
110,622 square kilometers
How much water area does Benin have?
2,000 square kilometers
How does the area of Benin compare to other places?
slightly smaller than Pennsylvania
What is the total length of Benin's land boundaries?
2,123 kilometers
What is the coastline length of Benin?
121 kilometers
How much land is irrigated in Benin?
530 square kilometers (2019)
What natural hazards affect Benin?
hot, dry, dusty harmattan wind may affect north from December to March
What is the population of Benin?
What percent of Benin's population is urban?
50.1% of total population (2023)
What is the rate of urbanization in Benin?
3.74% annual rate of change (2020-25 est.)
What are the geographic coordinates of Benin's capital?
What are the land boundaries of Benin?
Benin has 2,123 kilometers of land boundaries, including borders with Burkina Faso (386 kilometers), Niger (277 kilometers), Nigeria (809 kilometers), and Togo (651 kilometers).
What are Benin's maritime claims?
Benin claims an exclusive economic zone of 200 nautical miles.
What is the climate of Benin?
tropical; hot, humid in south; semiarid in north
What is the terrain of Benin like?
mostly flat to undulating plain; some hills and low mountains
What natural resources does Benin have?
Benin’s natural resources include small offshore oil deposits, limestone, marble, and timber.
What is the land use in Benin?

In Benin, 41.8% of the land is used for agriculture, including 31.4% arable land, 5.5% permanent crops, and 4.9% permanent pasture (2023 est.). Forest accounts for 28.5% and other land uses make up 29.7% (2023 est.).
What are the major environmental issues in Benin?
inadequate supplies of potable water; water pollution; poaching; deforestation; desertification; droughts
How is the population distributed in Benin?

The population of Benin is primarily located in the south, with the highest concentration in and around cities on the Atlantic coast. Much of the north remains sparsely populated, with higher concentrations in the west.
What languages are spoken in Benin?

Benin has 55 languages, with French as the official language. Major indigenous languages include Fon, Yom, and Yoruba in the south, and regionally important northern languages such as Bariba and Fulfulde.
What religions are practiced in Benin?

Muslim 27.7%, Roman Catholic 25.5%, Protestant 13.5% (Celestial 6.7%, Methodist 3.4%, other Protestant 3.4%), Vodoun 11.6%, other Christian 9.5%, other traditional religions 2.6%, other 2.6%, none 5.8% (2013 est.)
What ethnic groups are found in Benin?

Fon and related 38.4%, Adja and related 15.1%, Yoruba and related 12%, Bariba and related 9.6%, Fulani and related 8.6%, Ottamari and related 6.1%, Yoa-Lokpa and related 4.3%, Dendi and related 2.9%, other 0.9%, foreigner 1.9% (2013 est.)
What is the median age in Benin?
The median age in Benin is 17.2 years (2024 est.).
What is the capital of Benin?
Porto-Novo is Benin’s constitutional capital, while Cotonou is the seat of government.
Where is Burundi located?
Central Africa, east of the Democratic Republic of the Congo, west of Tanzania
What are the geographic coordinates of Burundi?
What map region is Burundi in?
Africa
How much land area does Burundi have?
25,680 square kilometers
How much water area does Burundi have?
2,150 square kilometers
How does the area of Burundi compare to other places?
slightly smaller than Maryland
What is the total length of Burundi's land boundaries?
1,140 kilometers
What is the coastline length of Burundi?
0 kilometers 0 kilometers as the country is landlocked.
What are Burundi's maritime claims?
This country has no maritime claims because it is a landlocked country.
What is the terrain of Burundi like?
hilly and mountainous, dropping to a plateau in east, some plains
How much land is irrigated in Burundi?
230 square kilometers (2012)
What is the population of Burundi?
What percent of Burundi's population is urban?
14.8% of total population (2023)
What is the rate of urbanization in Burundi?
5.43% annual rate of change (2020-25 est.)
What is the capital of Burundi?
Gitega (political capital), Bujumbura (commercial capital)
What are the geographic coordinates of Burundi's capital?
What are the land boundaries of Burundi?
Burundi has 1,140 kilometers of land boundaries, including borders with the Democratic Republic of the Congo (236 kilometers), Rwanda (315 kilometers), and Tanzania (589 kilometers).
What is the climate of Burundi?

Burundi has an equatorial climate on a high plateau with considerable altitude variation. It has two wet seasons (February to May and September to November) and two dry seasons (June to August and December to January), with average annual rainfall of about 150 cm.
What natural resources does Burundi have?

Burundi’s natural resources include nickel, uranium, rare earth oxides, peat, cobalt, copper, platinum, vanadium, arable land, hydropower, niobium, tantalum, gold, tin, tungsten, kaolin, and limestone.
What is the land use in Burundi?

In Burundi, 83.9% of the land is used for agriculture, including 51.4% arable land, 13.6% permanent crops, and 18.8% permanent pasture (2023 est.). Forest accounts for 10.9% and other land uses make up 5.2% (2023 est.).
What natural hazards affect Burundi?
flooding; landslides; drought
What are the major environmental issues in Burundi?
soil erosion from overgrazing and agricultural expansion; deforestation; wildlife habitat loss
How is the population distributed in Burundi?

Burundi is one of Africa’s most densely populated countries, with concentrations tending to be in the north and along the northern shore of Lake Tanganyika in the west. Most people live on farms near areas of fertile volcanic soil.
What languages are spoken in Burundi?

Languages in Burundi include Kirundi (official), French (official), English (official), and Swahili. Spoken Kirundi is nearly universal, and the data represent languages read and written by people age 10 and older (2008 est.).
What religions are practiced in Burundi?
Christian 93.9% (Roman Catholic 58.6%, Protestant 35.3% [includes Adventist 2.7% and other Protestant religions 32.6%]), Muslim 3.4%, other 1.3%, none 1.3% (2016-17 est.)
What ethnic groups are found in Burundi?
Burundi’s ethnic groups include Hutu, Tutsi, Twa, and South Asian.
What is the median age in Burundi?
The median age in Burundi is 18.4 years (2024 est.).
Where is Chad located?
Central Africa, south of Libya
What are the geographic coordinates of Chad?
What map region is Chad in?
Africa
How much land area does Chad have?
1,259,200 square kilometers
How much water area does Chad have?
24,800 square kilometers
What is the total length of Chad's land boundaries?
6,406 kilometers
What is the coastline length of Chad?
0 kilometers 0 kilometers as the country is landlocked.
What are Chad's maritime claims?
This country has no maritime claims because it is a landlocked country.
What is the climate of Chad?
tropical in south, desert in north
How much land is irrigated in Chad?
300 square kilometers (2012)
What is the population of Chad?
What percent of Chad's population is urban?
24.4% of total population (2023)
What is the rate of urbanization in Chad?
4.1% annual rate of change (2020-25 est.)
What is the capital of Chad?
N'Djamena
What are the geographic coordinates of Chad's capital?
How does the area of Chad compare to other places?
almost nine times the size of New York state; slightly more than three times the size of California
What are the land boundaries of Chad?

Chad has 6,406 kilometers of land boundaries, including borders with Cameroon (1,116 kilometers), the Central African Republic (1,556 kilometers), Libya (1,050 kilometers), Niger (1,196 kilometers), Nigeria (85 kilometers), and Sudan (1,403 kilometers).
What is the terrain of Chad like?
broad, arid plains in center, desert in north, mountains in northwest, lowlands in south
What natural resources does Chad have?
Chad’s natural resources include petroleum, uranium, natron, kaolin, fish from Lake Chad, gold, limestone, sand and gravel, and salt.
What is the land use in Chad?

In Chad, 40% of the land is used for agriculture, including 4.2% arable land, 0% permanent crops, and 35.7% permanent pasture (2023 est.). Forest accounts for 3.1% and other land uses make up 57% (2023 est.).
What natural hazards affect Chad?
hot, dry, dusty harmattan winds occur in north; periodic droughts; locust plagues
What are the major environmental issues in Chad?
inadequate supplies of potable water; soil and water pollution from improper waste disposal in rural areas and poor farming practices; desertification
How is the population distributed in Chad?

The population of Chad is unevenly distributed due to contrasts in climate and physical geography, with the highest density in the southwest around Lake Chad and areas to the south. The Saharan zone in the north is the least densely populated.
What languages are spoken in Chad?
Languages in Chad include French (official), Arabic (official), Sara in the south, and more than 120 languages and dialects.
What religions are practiced in Chad?
Muslim 52.1%, Protestant 23.9%, Roman Catholic 20%, animist 0.3%, other Christian 0.2%, none 2.8%, unspecified 0.7% (2014-15 est.)
What ethnic groups are found in Chad?
Ethnic groups in Chad include Sara, Kanembu/Bornu/Buduma, Arab, Wadai/Maba/Masalit/Mimi, Gorane, Masa/Musseye/Musgum, and many others (2014-15 est.).
What is the median age in Chad?
The median age in Chad is 16.7 years (2024 est.).
Where is Republic of the Congo located?
Central Africa, bordering the South Atlantic Ocean, between Angola and Gabon

341,500 square kilometers

5,554 kilometers

20 square kilometers (2012)

seasonal flooding
What is the population of Republic of the Congo?

the population is primarily located in the south, in and around the capital of Brazzaville, as shown in this population distribution map
What percent of Republic of the Congo's population is urban?
69.2% of total population (2023)
What is the rate of urbanization in Republic of the Congo?
3.19% annual rate of change (2020-25 est.)
What is the capital of Republic of the Congo?
Brazzaville
What are the geographic coordinates of Republic of the Congo's capital?
Where is Democratic Republic of the Congo located?
Central Africa, northeast of Angola
How does the area of Republic of the Congo compare to other places?
slightly smaller than Montana; about twice the size of Florida
What are the land boundaries of Republic of the Congo?

The Republic of the Congo has 5,554 kilometers of land boundaries, including borders with Angola (231 kilometers), Cameroon (494 kilometers), the Central African Republic (487 kilometers), the Democratic Republic of the Congo (1,775 kilometers), and Gabon (2,567 kilometers).
What are Republic of the Congo's maritime claims?
The Republic of the Congo claims a territorial sea of 12 nautical miles, a contiguous zone of 24 nautical miles, and an exclusive economic zone of 200 nautical miles.
What is the climate of Republic of the Congo?

The Republic of the Congo has a tropical climate with a rainy season from March to June and a dry season from June to October. Temperatures and humidity are persistently high, especially near the Equator.
What is the terrain of Republic of the Congo like?
coastal plain, southern basin, central plateau, northern basin
What natural resources does Republic of the Congo have?
The Republic of the Congo’s natural resources include petroleum, timber, potash, lead, zinc, uranium, copper, phosphates, gold, magnesium, natural gas, and hydropower.
What is the land use in Republic of the Congo?

In the Republic of the Congo, 31.3% of the land is used for agriculture, including 1.6% arable land, 0.4% permanent crops, and 29.3% permanent pasture (2022 est.). Forest accounts for 64.2% and other land uses make up 4.5% (2022 est.).
What are the major environmental issues in Republic of the Congo?
air pollution from vehicle emissions; water pollution from raw sewage; tap water not potable; deforestation; wildlife protection
What languages are spoken in Republic of the Congo?
Languages in the Republic of the Congo include French (official), French Lingala and Monokutuba as trade languages, and many local languages and dialects, of which Kikongo is the most widespread.
What religions are practiced in Republic of the Congo?
Roman Catholic 33.1%, Awakening Churches/Christian Revival 22.3%, Protestant 19.9%, Salutiste 2.2%, Muslim 1.6%, Kimbanguist 1.5%, other 8.1%, none 11.3% (2007 est.)
What ethnic groups are found in Republic of the Congo?

Kongo (Bakongo) 40.5%, Teke 16.9%, Mbochi 13.1%, foreigner 8.2%, Sangha 5.6%, Mbere/Mbeti/Kele 4.4%, Punu 4.3%, Pygmy 1.6%, Oubanguiens 1.6%, Duma 1.5%, Makaa 1.3%, other and unspecified 1% (2014-15 est.)
What is the median age in Republic of the Congo?
The median age in the Republic of the Congo is 20.7 years (2024 est.).
What are the geographic coordinates of Democratic Republic of the Congo?
What map region is Democratic Republic of the Congo in?
Africa
How much land area does Democratic Republic of the Congo have?
2,267,048 square kilometers
How much water area does Democratic Republic of the Congo have?
77,810 square kilometers
How does the area of Democratic Republic of the Congo compare to other places?
slightly less than one-fourth the size of the US
What is the total length of Democratic Republic of the Congo's land boundaries?
11,027 kilometers
What is the coastline length of Democratic Republic of the Congo?
37 kilometers
How much land is irrigated in Democratic Republic of the Congo?
110 square kilometers (2012)
What is the population of Democratic Republic of the Congo?
What percent of Democratic Republic of the Congo's population is urban?
47.4% of total population (2023)
What is the rate of urbanization in Democratic Republic of the Congo?
4.33% annual rate of change (2020-25 est.)
What is the capital of Democratic Republic of the Congo?
Kinshasa
What are the geographic coordinates of Democratic Republic of the Congo's capital?
What are the land boundaries of Democratic Republic of the Congo?

The Democratic Republic of the Congo has 11,027 kilometers of land boundaries, including borders with Angola (2,646 kilometers, including 225 kilometers around Cabinda Province), Burundi (236 kilometers), the Central African Republic (1,747 kilometers), the Republic of the Congo (1,775 kilometers), Rwanda (221 kilometers), South Sudan (714 kilometers), Tanzania (479 kilometers), Uganda (877 kilometers), and Zambia (2,332 kilometers).
What are Democratic Republic of the Congo's maritime claims?

The Democratic Republic of the Congo claims a territorial sea of 12 nautical miles, and since 2011 it has had a Common Interest Zone agreement with Angola for the mutual development of offshore resources.
What is the climate of Democratic Republic of the Congo?

The Democratic Republic of the Congo has a tropical climate that is hot and humid in the equatorial river basin and cooler and drier in the southern highlands. North of the Equator the wet season runs from April to October and the dry season from December to February, while south of the Equator the wet season runs from November to March and the dry season from April to October.
What is the terrain of Democratic Republic of the Congo like?
vast central basin is a low-lying plateau; mountains in east
What natural resources does Democratic Republic of the Congo have?

The Democratic Republic of the Congo’s natural resources include cobalt, copper, niobium, tantalum, petroleum, industrial and gem diamonds, gold, silver, zinc, manganese, tin, uranium, coal, hydropower, and timber.
What is the land use in Democratic Republic of the Congo?

In the Democratic Republic of the Congo, 15.5% of the land is used for agriculture, including 6.6% arable land, 0.9% permanent crops, and 8% permanent pasture (2023 est.). Forest accounts for 61.6% and other land uses make up 22.9% (2023 est.).
What natural hazards affect Democratic Republic of the Congo?

The Democratic Republic of the Congo has periodic droughts in the south, seasonal Congo River floods, and active volcanoes in the east along the Great Rift Valley. Nyiragongo is a major threat to Goma and is known for unusually fast-moving lava, while Nyamuragira is Africa’s most active volcano.
What are the major environmental issues in Democratic Republic of the Congo?
poaching; water pollution; deforestation from agriculture and wood used for fuel; soil erosion; damage from mining
How is the population distributed in Democratic Republic of the Congo?

Urban clusters are spread throughout the Democratic Republic of the Congo, particularly in the northeast along the borders with Uganda, Rwanda, and Burundi. The largest city is the capital, Kinshasa, in the west along the Congo River, and the south is the least densely populated.
What languages are spoken in Democratic Republic of the Congo?
Languages in the Democratic Republic of the Congo include French (official) and national languages such as Lingala, Kingwana (a dialect of Swahili), Kikongo, and Tshiluba.
What religions are practiced in Democratic Republic of the Congo?

Christian 93/1% (Roman Catholic 29.9%, Protestant 26.7%, other Christian 36.5%), Kimbanguist 2.8%, Muslim 1.3%, other (includes syncretic sects and indigenous beliefs) 1.2%, none 1.3%, unspecified 0.2% (2014 est.)
What ethnic groups are found in Democratic Republic of the Congo?

More than 200 African ethnic groups live in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, most of them Bantu. The four largest groups—Mongo, Luba, Kongo, and Mangbetu-Azande—make up about 45% of the population.
What is the median age in Democratic Republic of the Congo?
The median age in the Democratic Republic of the Congo is 16.9 years (2024 est.).
Where is Cameroon located?
Central Africa, bordering the Bight of Biafra, between Equatorial Guinea and Nigeria

How much land area does Cameroon have?
472,710 square kilometers
How much water area does Cameroon have?
2,730 square kilometers
What is the total length of Cameroon's land boundaries?
5,018 kilometers
What is the coastline length of Cameroon?
402 kilometers
What is the climate of Cameroon?
varies with terrain, from tropical along coast to semiarid and hot in north
How much land is irrigated in Cameroon?
290 square kilometers (2012)
What is the population of Cameroon?
How is the population distributed in Cameroon?
population concentrated in the west and north, with the interior of the country sparsely populated, as shown in this population distribution map
What percent of Cameroon's population is urban?
59.3% of total population (2023)
What is the rate of urbanization in Cameroon?
3.43% annual rate of change (2020-25 est.)
What is the capital of Cameroon?
Yaounde
What are the geographic coordinates of Cameroon's capital?
How does the area of Cameroon compare to other places?
slightly larger than California; about four times the size of Pennsylvania
What are the land boundaries of Cameroon?

Cameroon has 5,018 kilometers of land boundaries, including borders with the Central African Republic (901 kilometers), Chad (1,116 kilometers), the Republic of the Congo (494 kilometers), Equatorial Guinea (183 kilometers), Gabon (349 kilometers), and Nigeria (1,975 kilometers).
What are Cameroon's maritime claims?
Cameroon claims a territorial sea of 12 nautical miles and a contiguous zone of 24 nautical miles.
What is the terrain of Cameroon like?
Cameroon has diverse terrain, including a coastal plain in the southwest, a dissected plateau in the center, mountains in the west, and plains in the north.
What natural resources does Cameroon have?
Cameroon’s natural resources include petroleum, bauxite, iron ore, timber, and hydropower.
What is the land use in Cameroon?

What natural hazards affect Cameroon?

Cameroon faces volcanic activity, including periodic releases of poisonous gases from Lake Nyos and Lake Monoun. Mount Cameroon is the most frequently active volcano in West Africa and last erupted in 2000.
What are the major environmental issues in Cameroon?
Major environmental issues in Cameroon include deforestation, overgrazing, soil erosion, desertification, and poaching. Overfishing and overhunting are also concerns.

What ethnic groups are found in Cameroon?

Where is Antarctica located?
continent mostly south of the Antarctic Circle
What are the geographic coordinates of Antarctica?

Antarctic Region
How much land area does Antarctica have?
14.2 million square kilometers (285,000 square kilometers ice-free, 13.915 million square kilometers ice-covered) (est.)
How does the area of Antarctica compare to other places?
slightly less than 1.5 times the size of the US
What is the coastline length of Antarctica?
17,968 kilometers
What are Antarctica's maritime claims?

Australia, Chile, and Argentina claim Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) rights or similar over 200 nm extensions seaward from their continental claims, but like the claims themselves, these zones are not accepted by other countries; 22 of 29 Antarctic Treaty consultative parties have made no claims to Antarctic territory, although Russia and the United States have reserved the right to do so, and no country can make a new claim.
What is the climate of Antarctica?

Antarctica is the coldest, windiest, and driest continent on Earth, with severe low temperatures that vary with latitude, elevation, and distance from the ocean; East Antarctica is colder than West Antarctica because of its higher elevation, and the Antarctic Peninsula has the most moderate climate. Higher temperatures occur in January along the coast and average slightly below freezing, summers have continuous daylight, winters have continuous darkness, and persistent high pressure over the interior brings dry, subsiding air with very little cloud cover.
What is the terrain of Antarctica like?

Antarctica is about 99% thick continental ice sheet and 1% barren rock, with average elevations between 2,000 and 4,000 m and mountain ranges up to nearly 5,000 m. Ice-free coastal areas include parts of southern Victoria Land, Wilkes Land, the Antarctic Peninsula area, and parts of Ross Island on McMurdo Sound; glaciers form ice shelves along about half of the coastline, and floating ice shelves constitute 11% of the area of the continent.
What natural resources does Antarctica have?

Antarctica has iron ore, chromium, copper, gold, nickel, platinum and other minerals, and coal and hydrocarbons found in small noncommercial quantities; mineral exploitation except for scientific research is banned by the Environmental Protocol to the Antarctic Treaty. Krill, icefish, toothfish, and crab have been taken by commercial fisheries managed through the Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources (CCAMLR).
What natural hazards affect Antarctica?

Natural hazards in Antarctica include katabatic (gravity-driven) winds blowing coastward from the high interior, frequent blizzards near the foot of the plateau, cyclonic storms over the ocean moving clockwise along the coast, and large icebergs that may calve from ice shelf. Volcanism: volcanic activity occurs on Deception Island and isolated areas of West Antarctica, and other seismic activity is rare and weak.
What are the major environmental issues in Antarctica?
Major environmental issues in Antarctica include the size of the ozone hole over the continent and ice loss.
What is the population of Antarctica?

Antarctica has no permanent inhabitants, but staff is present at year-round and summer-only research stations. Note: 56 countries have signed the 1959 Antarctic Treaty, and 30 of those operate seasonal-only and year-round research stations; the population varies from approximately 5,000 in summer to 1,100 in winter, with about 1,000 support personnel on ships nearby; as of 2024, peak summer (December-February) maximum capacity in scientific stations is 4,713 total (Argentina 425, Australia 238, Belarus 15, Belgium 55, Brazil 64, Bulgaria 25, Chile 375, China 164, Czechia 32, Ecuador 35, Finland 16, France 136, France and Italy jointly 70, Germany 60, India 72, Italy 150, Japan 130, South Korea 158, New Zealand 85, Norway 60, Peru 30, Poland 41, Russia 211, South Africa 80, Spain 79, Sweden 16, Ukraine 15, United Kingdom 315, United States 1,495, Uruguay 66). Winter (June-August) maximum capacity in scientific stations is 1,056 total (Argentina 221, Australia 52, Brazil 15, Chile 114, China 32, France 24, France and Italy jointly 13, Germany 9, India 48, Japan 40, Netherlands 10, South Korea 25, NZ 11, Norway 7, Poland 16, Russia 125, South Africa 15, Ukraine 12, UK 44, US 215, Uruguay 8) (2024).

Where is French Southern and Antarctic Lands located?

French Southern and Antarctic Lands is located southeast and east of Africa, with islands in the southern Indian Ocean, some near Madagascar and others about equidistant between Africa, Antarctica, and Australia; note: it includes Ile Amsterdam, Ile Saint-Paul, Iles Crozet, Iles Kerguelen, Bassas da India, Europa Island, Glorioso Islands, Juan de Nova Island, and Tromelin Island, along with the French-claimed sector of Antarctica, Adelie Land; the US does not recognize the French claim to Adelie Land.
What are the geographic coordinates of French Southern and Antarctic Lands?

Ile Amsterdam (Ile Amsterdam et Ile Saint-Paul): 37 50 S, 77 32 E; Ile Saint-Paul (Ile Amsterdam et Ile Saint-Paul): 38 72 S, 77 53 E; Iles Crozet: 46 25 S, 51 00 E; Iles Kerguelen: 49 15 S, 69 35 E; Bassas da India (Iles Eparses): 21 30 S, 39 50 E; Europa Island (Iles Eparses): 22 20 S, 40 22 E; Glorioso Islands (Iles Eparses): 11 30 S, 47 20 E; Juan de Nova Island (Iles Eparses): 17 03 S, 42 45 E; Tromelin Island (Iles Eparses): 15 52 S, 54 25 E.
How does the area of French Southern and Antarctic Lands compare to other places?

Ile Amsterdam (Ile Amsterdam et Ile Saint-Paul) is less than one-half the size of Washington, D.C.; Ile Saint-Paul (Ile Amsterdam et Ile Saint-Paul) is more than 10 times the size of the National Mall in Washington, D.C.; Iles Crozet is about twice the size of Washington, D.C.; Iles Kerguelen is slightly larger than Delaware; Bassas da India (Iles Eparses) has land area about one-third the size of the National Mall in Washington, D.C.; Europa Island (Iles Eparses) is about one-sixth the size of Washington, D.C.; Glorioso Islands (Iles Eparses) is about eight times the size of the National Mall in Washington, D.C.; Juan de Nova Island (Iles Eparses) is about seven times the size of the National Mall in Washington, D.C.; Tromelin Island (Iles Eparses) is about 1.7 times the size of the National Mall in Washington, D.C.

What are French Southern and Antarctic Lands's maritime claims?

French Southern and Antarctic Lands claims a territorial sea of 12 nm and an exclusive economic zone of 200 nm from Iles Kerguelen and Iles Eparses (does not include the rest of the territory); Juan de Nova Island and Tromelin Island claim a continental shelf of 200-m depth or to the depth of exploitation.
What is the climate of French Southern and Antarctic Lands?

Ile Amsterdam et Ile Saint-Paul has an oceanic climate with persistent westerly winds and high humidity; Iles Crozet is windy, cold, wet, and cloudy; Iles Kerguelen is oceanic, cold, overcast, and windy; Iles Eparses is tropical.
What is the terrain of French Southern and Antarctic Lands like?

Ile Amsterdam (Ile Amsterdam et Ile Saint-Paul) is a volcanic island with steep coastal cliffs and a large plateau in the center floor of the volcano; Ile Saint-Paul (Ile Amsterdam et Ile Saint-Paul) is triangular in shape, rocky with steep cliffs on the eastern side, is the top of a volcano, and has active thermal springs; Iles Crozet is a large archipelago formed from the Crozet Plateau and is divided into two groups of islands; Iles Kerguelen has high mountains, hills, valleys, plains, and peninsulas; Bassas da India (Iles Eparses) is an atoll, awash at high tide, with a shallow (15 m) lagoon; Europa Island, Glorioso Islands, and Juan de Nova Island are low, flat, and sandy; Tromelin Island (Iles Eparses) is low, flat, sandy, and likely a volcanic seamount.
What natural resources does French Southern and Antarctic Lands have?
French Southern and Antarctic Lands has fish and crayfish; note: Glorioso Islands and Tromelin Island (Iles Eparses) have guano, phosphates, and coconuts.
What natural hazards affect French Southern and Antarctic Lands?

Natural hazards include inactive volcanoes on Ile Amsterdam and Ile Saint-Paul, periodic cyclones affecting Iles Éparses, and Bassas da India being a maritime hazard because it is under water for three hours before and after high tide. Volcanism: Reunion Island - Piton de la Fournaise (2,632 m) has erupted many times in recent years and is one of the world's most active volcanoes; although rare, eruptions outside the volcano's caldera could threaten nearby cities.
What are the major environmental issues in French Southern and Antarctic Lands?
Major environmental issues include problems from the introduction of foreign species on Iles Crozet and overfishing of Patagonian toothfish around Iles Crozet and Iles Kerguelen.

What are Baker Island, Howland Island, Jarvis Island, Johnston Atoll, Kingman Reef, Midway Islands, Palmyra Atoll's maritime claims?

What is the climate of Baker Island, Howland Island, Jarvis Island, Johnston Atoll, Kingman Reef, Midway Islands, Palmyra Atoll?

Baker, Howland, and Jarvis Islands: equatorial; scant rainfall, constant wind, burning sun. Johnston Atoll and Kingman Reef: tropical, but generally dry; consistent northeast trade winds with little seasonal temperature variation. Midway Islands: subtropical with cool, moist winters (December to February) and warm, dry summers (May to October); moderated by prevailing easterly winds; most of the 107 cm of annual rainfall occurs during the winter. Palmyra Atoll: equatorial, hot; located within the low pressure area of the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) where the northeast and southeast trade winds meet, it is extremely wet with between 400-500 cm of rainfall each year.
What natural hazards affect Baker Island, Howland Island, Jarvis Island, Johnston Atoll, Kingman Reef, Midway Islands, Palmyra Atoll?

Baker, Howland, and Jarvis Islands: the narrow fringing reef around the island poses a maritime hazard. Kingman Reef: wet or awash most of the time; maximum elevation of less than 2 m makes the reef a maritime hazard.

Baker Island: no natural freshwater resources. Howland Island: no natural freshwater resources. Jarvis Island: no natural freshwater resources. Johnston Atoll: no natural freshwater resources; invasion of non-native species. Midway Islands: pollution from plastic; predominantly non-native plant species. Kingman Reef: none. Palmyra Atoll: none.

Where is France located?

Metropolitan France: Western Europe, bordering the Bay of Biscay and English Channel, between Belgium and Spain, southeast of the UK; bordering the Mediterranean Sea, between Italy and Spain. French Guiana: Northern South America, bordering the North Atlantic Ocean, between Brazil and Suriname. Guadeloupe: Caribbean, islands between the Caribbean Sea and the North Atlantic Ocean, southeast of Puerto Rico. Martinique: Caribbean, island between the Caribbean Sea and North Atlantic Ocean, north of Trinidad and Tobago. Mayotte: Southern Indian Ocean, island in the Mozambique Channel, about halfway between northern Madagascar and northern Mozambique. Reunion: Southern Africa, island in the Indian Ocean, east of Madagascar.

What is the climate of France?

What is the terrain of France like?

Metropolitan France is mostly flat plains or gently rolling hills in north and west, with mountainous areas in the remainder, especially Pyrenees in south and Alps in east. French Guiana has low-lying coastal plains rising to hills and small mountains. Guadeloupe: Basse-Terre is volcanic in origin with interior mountains, while Grande-Terre is low limestone formation; most of the seven other islands are volcanic in origin. Martinique is mountainous with an indented coastline and a dormant volcano. Mayotte is generally undulating, with deep ravines and ancient volcanic peaks. Reunion is mostly rugged and mountainous, with fertile lowlands along the coast.
What natural resources does France have?

Metropolitan France has coal, iron ore, bauxite, zinc, uranium, antimony, arsenic, potash, feldspar, fluorspar, gypsum, timber, arable land, and fish; French Guiana has gold deposits, petroleum, kaolin, niobium, tantalum, and clay.
What natural hazards affect France?

Metropolitan France faces flooding, avalanches, midwinter windstorms, drought, and forest fires in the south; overseas departments face hurricanes (cyclones) and flooding. Volcanism: Montagne Pelée (1,394 m) on Martinique is the most active volcano of the Lesser Antilles arc, although it last erupted in 1932; a catastrophic eruption in 1902 destroyed the city of St. Pierre, killing an estimated 30,000 people; La Soufrière (1,467 m) on Guadeloupe has also had explosive eruptions in recent years.
What are the major environmental issues in France?

Why have the indigenous peoples of Asia's remote highland slopes and mountainous regions maintained their unique cultural traditions?

The indigenous peoples of the remote highland slopes and mountainous regions have maintained their own idiosyncratic ritual and artistic traditions because they are somewhat isolated from the influences that have shaped the rest of the country.
What mountain range runs along a northwest-southeast axis in Laos, Asia?
The Annamese Cordillera (Chaîne Annamitique) is the principal mountain range that lies along a northwest-southeast axis in Laos.
What is the characteristic of the coastal plain in Asia?
The coastal plain is narrow and discontinuous, almost disappearing in places. It is formed of river-deposited alluvium and marine sediments, which alternate with rocky beaches.
What type of climate does Malaysia in Southeast Asia have?
Malaysia has an equatorial climate.
Where in Asia can the Rafflesia arnoldii, with the world's largest known flower, be found?

The Rafflesia arnoldii can be found in the Malaysian rainforest. There are several thousand species of vascular plants, including more than 2,000 species of trees, as well as the parasitic Rafflesia arnoldii of the Rafflesiaceae family, which bears the world’s largest known flower, measuring nearly 3 feet (1 metre) in diameter.
What community in Southeast Asia includes those of mixed Chinese and Malay ancestry?
The Baba Chinese community includes those of mixed Chinese and Malay ancestry who speak a Malay patois but otherwise remain Chinese in customs, manners, and habit.
Describe the key features of the region in Asia where the Melanau people traditionally reside, including its physical features and economy?
Sarawak's south-central coastal wetlands between the city of Bintulu and the Rajang River are the traditional territory of the Melanau. The Melanau are known for producing starch from sago palms.
Describe the physical features and climate of Mongolia in the context of eastern Asia?

Landlocked Mongolia is located between Russia to the north and China to the south, deep within the interior of eastern Asia far from any ocean. The country has a marked continental climate, with long cold winters and short cool-to-hot summers. Its variety of scenery consists largely of upland steppes, semideserts, and deserts, although in the west and north forested high mountain ranges alternate with lake-dotted basins. Mongolia is largely a plateau, with an average elevation of about 5,180 feet (1,580 metres) above sea level.
Where in Asia does the Selenge River ultimately drain? is not needed. Here is the output?
The Selenge River ultimately drains into Lake Baikal.
What is the primary use of coal produced in Asia's Mongolia region?

The chief mineral produced is coal, which is primarily for domestic use, although the newer coalfields of Khöshööt near Khovd in the west and Tavantolgoi in the southern Gobi have begun exporting their coal to China.
What country in Asia is known for its variegated grassland and desert landscapes?
Mongolia is known for its variegated grassland and desert landscapes.
What region in Asia is characterized by broad basins between the Churia and Mahābhārat mountain ranges?

The region in Asia characterized by broad basins between the Churia and Mahābhārat mountain ranges is the Inner Tarai. These basins are from 2,000 to 3,000 feet high, about 10 miles wide, and 20 to 40 miles long. They have been cleared of forests and savanna grass to provide timber and areas for cultivation.
What region in Asia is separated by a 2.5-mile-wide demilitarized zone?
North Korea faces South Korea across a demilitarized zone (DMZ) 2.5 miles (4 km) wide that was established by the terms of the 1953 armistice.
Why have podzols developed in the Kaema Highlands of Asia?

What seas bound the Philippine archipelago in Southeast Asia?

Describe the key physical features of Asia's Philippines, including its volcanic areas, drainage patterns, and major rivers?

The Philippines is characterized by distinct volcanic areas, notable rivers, and specific drainage patterns. The several distinct volcanic areas are in south-central and southern Luzon and on the islands of Negros, Mindanao, Jolo, and elsewhere. Tremors and earthquakes are common. The most important rivers of the Philippines are the Cagayan, Agno, Pampanga, Pasig, and Bicol on Luzon and the Mindanao (Río Grande de Mindanao) and Agusan on Mindanao. The northern plain between the Sierra Madre and the Cordillera Central is drained by the Cagayan, while the central plain is drained in the north by the Agno and in the south by the Pampanga.
Where in Asia is the tamarau, a species of small water buffalo, found?
The tamarau, a species of small water buffalo (Anoa mindorensis), is found only on Mindoro, Philippines.
What natural resources are extracted off the northwest coast of Palawan in Asia?

Where in Asia is Saudi Arabia located?
Saudi Arabia is located in the Middle East, on the Arabian Peninsula in Asia.
Describe the key features of religious practices and restrictions in Asia, focusing on a specific country, in terms of human geography?

In Saudi Arabia, the key features of religious practices and restrictions include a predominantly Muslim population with restrictions on other faiths. Shiʿis make up a small portion of the population and are found mostly in the oases of Al-Hasa and Al-Qaṭīf in the eastern part of the country. Most Shiʿis are Twelver, with small numbers of Ismāʿīlīs. The country's once small Jewish population is now apparently extinct. Other religions are practiced among foreign workers, who also include Christians. Public worship and display by non-Muslim faiths is prohibited. Public displays by non-Wahhābī Muslim groups, including other Sunni sects, have been limited and even banned by the government.
Where is the largest port in Southeast Asia located?
Singapore is the largest port in Southeast Asia and one of the busiest in the world.
Which part of Asia is home to the volcanic island of Jeju?
The volcanic island of Jeju is located in East Asia, specifically in South Korea.
What region is referred to as having a broadly common commercial and cultural inheritance throughout mainland and insular Southeast Asia?
Southeast Asia is referred to as having a broadly common commercial and cultural inheritance throughout mainland and insular Southeast Asia.
How has the interaction between the Sunda Shelf and the oceanic crust to the south resulted in the formation of the Greater and Lesser Sunda islands in Asia?

The interaction between the Sunda Shelf and the oceanic crust to the south has resulted in the formation of the Greater and Lesser Sunda islands through the creation of a vast volcanic arc where the shelf meets and overrides the oceanic crust.
What region in Asia receives more than 60 inches of rainfall annually?
Much of Southeast Asia receives more than 60 inches (1,500 millimeters) of rainfall annually.
Why does the river in Sri Lanka, Asia, have a larger and less seasonally varied flow compared to other rivers in the Dry Zone?
The river has a larger and less seasonally varied flow than other Dry Zone rivers because a part of its catchment is well within the Wet Zone.

Where in Asia is hydroelectric power generation most prevalent due to fast-flowing mountain streams?

Tajikistan is among the countries with the greatest potential for hydroelectric power in the world, and most of the electric power generated in Tajikistan is hydroelectric. Some fast-flowing mountain streams have been exploited as hydroelectric power sources.
How did the uplifting along crustal faults in Asia result in the formation of the Khorat Plateau's distinct topography?

The uplifting along two perpendicularly arranged crustal faults created the Khorat Plateau's distinct topography. The faults, one trending north-south in the west and the other east-west in the south, tilted the underlying sedimentary rocks. This tilting created ranges of low hills and mountains along the western and southern edges of the plateau: the Phetchabun and Dangrek mountains, respectively.
What region of Asia is Thailand located in?
Thailand is located in mainland Southeast Asia.
Describe the key features of human geography in terms of language and cultural identity in Asia, specifically in Thailand?

Thailand's population is characterized by a diverse range of languages and cultural identities. Although the vast majority of the inhabitants are descendants of speakers of Tai languages who have been dominant in the area since the late 13th century, the population also includes numerous non-Tai peoples. Members of the largest indigenous minority speak a dialect of Malay. Other significant indigenous minorities include speakers of Mon, Khmer, and other Mon-Khmer languages of the Austroasiatic family. In the uplands of western and northern Thailand are found peoples who speak languages belonging to several other language families. Thailand is also home to large numbers of immigrants and their descendants, most from China but some from South Asia. Most members of indigenous and immigrant communities in Thailand identify strongly with Thai national culture and are speakers of Thai.
Where in Asia is the Wat Chiang Man, Thailand's oldest Buddhist temple, located?
The Wat Chiang Man is located in Chiang Mai, Thailand.
Why are the language and customs of the southern Thai similar to those of the Thai of central Thailand in Asia?
The language and customs of the southern Thai are similar to those of the Thai of central Thailand because of the region's historical ties to the later Siamese kingdoms.
Where in Asia was Don Muang International Airport located?

What type of climate does Turkmenistan have due to its position deep inside Asia?

Describe the physical features and ecosystems of the Ardennes region in Europe?

The Ardennes region is a plateau cut deeply by the Meuse River and its tributaries. Its higher points contain peat bogs and have poor drainage; these uplands are unsuitable as cropland. The Ardennes is part of the Hercynian orogenic belt of mountain ranges, which reaches from western Ireland into Germany and was formed roughly 300 to 400 million years ago, during the Paleozoic Era.
Where in Europe is the Flemish language predominantly spoken?
The Flemish language is predominantly spoken in the north of Belgium. The Flemings, who constitute more than half of Belgium’s population, speak Flemish, which is equivalent to Dutch.
Where in Europe is Bosnia and Herzegovina located?

What are the key features of the physical geography of Europe's region characterized by the Karst and surrounding areas?

The key features of the physical geography of the region characterized by the Karst and surrounding areas are high peaks, arid limestone plateaus, caves, potholes, and underground drainage. The highest peak, reaching 7,828 feet (2,386 metres), is Maglić, near the border with Montenegro. The Karst region contains caves, potholes, and underground drainage. The uplands are often bare and denuded, but depressions known as poljes are covered with alluvial soil suitable for agriculture. Elevations of more than 6,000 feet (1,800 metres) are common, and the plateaus descend abruptly toward the Adriatic Sea.
What mountain range separates Bosnia and Herzegovina from the Mediterranean climate in Europe?
The Dinaric Alps separate Bosnia and Herzegovina from the Mediterranean climate.
Describe the key physical features that mark the northern frontier of Bulgaria in Europe?

Which country in Europe is among the world’s largest exporters of fish products?
Denmark is among the world’s largest exporters of fish products.
What change occurred in Europe's power plants regarding their fuel sources?
The construction of additional coal-burning power plants was banned, and some plants began using biofuels.
Where is one of the busiest airports in Europe located?
Kastrup, near Copenhagen, is one of the busiest airports in Europe.
Which country in Europe has a capital city called Tallinn?
Estonia has a capital city called Tallinn.
What is considered the dividing line between Europe and Asia by some geographers?
The crest of the Greater Caucasus range is considered the dividing line between Europe and Asia by some geographers, placing Ciscaucasia in Europe and Transcaucasia in Asia.
What are the key features of Europe in terms of its natural resources and human geography?

Europe enjoys a considerable resource base of soil, forest, sea, and minerals (notably coal), but its people are increasingly its principal resource. The continent, excluding Russia, contains less than one-tenth of the world's total population, but in general its people are well educated and highly skilled. Europe also supports high densities of population, concentrated in urban-industrial regions.
What are the key features of Europe's physical landscape, including its major geological structures and landforms?

Europe's physical landscape is characterized by varied geological structures and landforms. The largest area of oldest rocks is the Baltic Shield, which has been eroded down to a low relief, while the youngest rocks occur in the Alpine system, forming high mountains. Between these belts are basins of sedimentary rocks that form rolling hills, as in the Paris Basin and southeastern England, or extensive plains, as in the Russian Platform. The North Sea is a submarine sedimentary basin on the shallow-water continental margin of the Atlantic Ocean. Iceland is a volcanic island situated on the Mid-Atlantic Ridge within the still-opening Atlantic Ocean.
What are the key features of the geological structure and stratigraphy of Europe, particularly in terms of its Precambrian rocks and their tectonic environment?

Compared with most of the other continents, Europe has few exposed rocks from Precambrian time. Some granitic gneisses, which are more than 3 billion years old, crop out in the northern Baltic Shield, the Ukrainian Massif, and northwestern Scotland. Those rocks were recrystallized at a depth of about 12 miles (20 km) in the Archean crust, but their tectonic environment is poorly understood. The shield has a composite origin, containing remnants of several Precambrian orogenic belts. About 540 to 500 million years ago a series of new oceans opened, and their eventual closure gave rise to the Caledonian, Hercynian, and Uralian orogenic belts. Formation of the belts gave rise to the supercontinent of Pangea; its fragmentation, beginning about 200 million years ago, gave rise to a new ocean, the Tethys Sea. Closure of that ocean, by subduction and plate-tectonic processes, led to the Alpine orogeny.
Why have many of the rocks in the Bohemian Massif in Europe been transformed into schists, gneisses, and amphibolites?

Many of the rocks in the Bohemian Massif have been transformed into schists, gneisses, and amphibolites because they were strongly deformed in several Precambrian orogenies. The rocks formed in the Late Archean (about 2.7 billion years ago) or Early Proterozoic (Svecofennian times) or even later in the Proterozoic (about 1 billion years ago). They were accompanied by a variety of granites.
Where is the Caledonian orogenic belt located in Europe?

The Caledonian orogenic belt is located from Ireland and Wales through northern England and Scotland to western Norway and northward to Finnmark in northern Norway. The belt is confined between the Baltic Shield and the Precambrian belt of northwestern Scotland.
Describe the key physical features of the Hercynian orogeny in Europe, including the resulting geological formations and structures?

The Hercynian orogeny in Europe is characterized by an island arc with lavas and granites in Brittany resulting from subduction of the ocean floor, a main suture zone extending from the south side of Brittany to the Massif Central, and evidence of extensive thrusting. Throughout much of Europe, there is evidence of extensive thrusting, implying that there was appreciable thickening of the continental crust and the formation of a Tibetan-style plateau across the Hercynian orogeny.
What continent was compressed northward into Europe during the Cenozoic Alpine orogeny?
Africa was compressed northward into Europe during the Cenozoic Alpine orogeny.
What are the key features of the physical landscape of Europe that were shaped by glaciers?

Glaciers shaped many physical forms of northern and Alpine Europe through glacial erosion and weathering, resulting in areas with masses of transported material. Many physical forms of northern and Alpine Europe resulted from glacial erosion, supplemented by weathering, and the surfaces of areas where the glaciers eventually withered away consisted of masses of transported material. Southern Scandinavia, southern Finland, the Swiss Plateau, and the North European Plain were thickly plastered with a variety of forms, including boulder-studded clay, gravels, sands, and the windblown deposits known as loess. New drainage patterns were formed as well.
What are the key features of the physical configuration of Europe that distinguish its western part from its eastern part?

A contrast exists between the configuration of peninsular, or western, Europe and that of eastern Europe. A division is made by a line linking the base of the peninsula of Jutland with the head of the Adriatic Sea. The western part of the continent has a high proportion of coastline with good maritime access and often with inland penetration by means of navigable rivers.
What are the key features of the physical landscape in Europe, including notable geological deposits and landforms?

The key features of the physical landscape in Europe include glacial deposition areas, windblown loess deposits, and various landforms shaped by glacial activity. The northern lowlands are areas of glacial deposition, diversified by features such as the Valdai Hills of western Russia, deposits of boulder clay, sands, and gravels, glacial lakes, and the Pripet Marshes, a large ill-drained area of Belarus and Ukraine. A southeast-northwest zone of windblown loess deposits has accumulated from eastern Britain to Ukraine. The Börde belt lies at the northern foot of the Central European Uplands and the Carpathians. South of the limits of the northern glacial ice are vales and hills, with the Paris and London basins being typical examples.
Why do Alpine rivers in Europe experience flooding when the warm foehn wind occurs?
Alpine rivers in Europe experience flooding when the warm foehn wind rapidly melts the snow.
What are the key features of the physical geography and ecosystems found in Europe, including notable landforms and soil patterns?

Europe's physical geography and ecosystems are characterized by diverse landforms and soil patterns. Fens, such as the polders in the Netherlands and the lowlands in eastern England, are made up of either alluvium or peat and require continuous pumping to be drained effectively. The continent's largest marshland is the Pripet Marshes of Belarus and Ukraine. The soil patterns of Europe are clearly and zonally arranged in the East European Plain, but are more complicated in the rest of the continent due to varied geology and relief.
What type of soil is commonly found in southern Europe's valleys and depressions?
A bright red soil (terra rossa), heavy and clay-rich, is found in many valleys and depressions in southern Europe.
What region in southern Europe experiences hot and dry north winds during summer?
The Mediterranean region experiences hot and dry north and northeast summer winds called etesian by the ancient Greeks.
What type of climate is found at the core of Europe?

The central European, or transitional, type of climate is found at the core of Europe, south and east of the maritime type, west of the much larger continental type, and north of the Mediterranean type.
Which city in southern Europe has an annual mean rainfall of roughly 16 inches?
Athens has an annual mean rainfall of roughly 16 inches (400 mm).
Why did certain regions in Europe remain treeless during postglacial times?
Certain regions in Europe remained treeless during postglacial times because of extreme cold, high elevation, bad drainage, or exposure to persistent gales.
How has human activity influenced the current vegetation patterns in Europe?

Human activity has significantly influenced the current vegetation patterns in Europe. Humans have not only shaped the vegetation zones of Europe but also introduced many individual species of plants, both wild and cultivated, that commonly grow on the continent. They also have introduced many plants originally from other parts of the world. Although some imported crops, such as citrus fruits, sugarcane, and rice, can grow only marginally in Europe, and then often by irrigation, many others thrive throughout the continent.
Where in Europe do sables still survive?
Sables survive in the northeastern forests of European Russia.
What is the approximate number of culturally distinct groups in Europe?
There are approximately 160 culturally distinct groups in Europe.
What are the key features of the linguistic diversity in Europe, including the language families and their geographical distribution across the continent?

Europe's linguistic diversity is characterized by the presence of multiple language families, primarily Indo-European, with other families also represented. Non-Indo-European languages are spoken on the continent, including the Basque language in western Europe, specifically in the western Pyrenees. In northeastern and central Europe, languages such as Finnish, Sami, Estonian, and Hungarian belong to the Uralic language family. Turkic languages are spoken in parts of the Balkan and Caucasus regions, as well as in southern Russia.
What are the key features of the human geography of Europe in terms of population growth and settlement patterns?

The key features of Europe's human geography are characterized by slowed population growth by the end of the 20th century and a shift in settlement patterns over time. By the early 21st century, Europe’s population had fallen to about one-tenth of the world total. In antiquity, the focus of settlement was in southern Europe, but the south lost its numerical domination from medieval times onward, as settlement developed vigorously in western and central Europe and, later still, as the steppe lands of Ukraine and Hungary were settled for crop farming.
Why has water recycling become a common practice in certain European rivers, such as the Thames and Elbe?
Water is recycled many times in certain European rivers, such as the Thames and Elbe, in reaction to water shortages.
Why has the population in Finland concentrated in the southern third of the country, particularly around Helsinki, in continental Europe?

The harsh climate in the northern part of the country has resulted in the concentration of the population in the southern third of Finland, with about one-fifth of the country’s population living in and around Helsinki, Finland’s largest city and continental Europe’s northernmost capital.
Where in Europe is the Turun archipelago located?
The Turun archipelago is located in southwest Finland.
Where in Europe is a country with régions that have been granted autonomy?

France, a country in northwestern Europe, has régions that have been granted autonomy. Today, as in the Middle Ages, central authority is vested in the state, even though a measure of autonomy has been granted to the country’s régions in recent decades.
What part of Europe was directly sculpted by great ice sheets?
The northern part of Europe was directly sculpted by the great ice sheets.
What are the key features of the physical geography of the Massif Central region in Europe?

The Massif Central region is characterized by a series of hill masses that overlook the lowlands of the Rhône-Saône river valley and the région of Languedoc-Roussillon. Between the hill masses lie infolded coal deposits at locations such as Alès, Decazeville, Saint-Étienne, and Blanzy (Le Creusot) that are of more historical than contemporary importance. To the southwest, the rocks of the massif are overlain by a great thickness of limestones (causses) from the Jurassic Period (about 200 to 145 million years ago). This portion of the massif is lacking in surface water, little populated, and crossed by rivers that trench dramatic gorges, notably that of the Tarn.
What is the highest point in the mountain chain that extends across Europe?
The highest point in the mountain chain that extends across Europe is Mont Blanc (15,771 feet [4,807 metres]).
Why does the Garonne river have irregular outflow in Europe?
The Garonne river has irregular outflow due to the oceanic rainfall in winter and snow melt in spring, resulting in high waters, and meagre flows in summer and autumn.
Where are the lakes Annecy and Bourget, both located within Europe, found?
The lakes Annecy and Bourget are located at the western periphery of the Alps.
What are the key features of human geography in rural Europe, including the impact of farming practices on soil quality and the environment?

Human action is a crucial factor in determining soil quality in rural Europe. Generally, farmers have maintained or improved soil quality by draining and manuring; the activities of Flemish peasants, who created their soil out of a marshy wilderness, are especially noteworthy. Not all human intervention has been successful, however, as seen in the degradation of brown earths under heath in western France, which is a result of human clearance and grazing practices.
Why did various migrant groups settle permanently in France as they moved through Europe from other regions?
Various migrant groups settled permanently in France because they were unable to migrate any farther as they moved through Europe from other regions.
Where in Europe is one of the largest Muslim populations found?

France has one of Europe’s largest Muslim populations: an estimated 5,000,000 Muslims, a sizable percentage of them living in and around Marseille in southeastern France, as well as in Paris and Lyon.
What are the key features of the bocage landscape found in parts of Europe, including its physical characteristics and geographical distribution?

The key features of the bocage landscape are small fields surrounded by drainage ditches and high earthen banks, with impenetrable hedges arching over narrow sunken lanes. Bocage is found in Brittany, on the northern, western, and southern fringes of the Paris Basin, such as in Normandy, as well as in the western and northern parts of the Massif Central, parts of Aquitaine, and the Pyrenean region.
What regions in Europe experienced decline and out-migration due to deindustrialization?
The older industrial regions, such as Nord–Pas-de-Calais and Lorraine, were in decline and had become regions of out-migration.
Where is Germany located in terms of a broader European region?
Germany is located in the western part of central Europe.
Why did the Zugspitze become Germany's highest summit due to the geological processes that shaped Europe?

The Zugspitze is Germany's highest summit because it was raised by the earth movements that created the Alps, Europe's highest and youngest fold mountains, which began some 37 to 24 million years ago.
What landform separates the Black Forest in southern Germany from the Vosges massif in France in Europe?

The Rhine Rift Valley separates the Black Forest in southern Germany from the Vosges massif in France. The Black Forest was once continuous with the Vosges massif, but they were broken apart through the sinking of a central strip to form the Rhine Rift Valley, which extends 185 miles (300 km) in length.
What are the key features of the physical landscape in a specific region of Europe, including its geological formations and volcanic activity?

The key features of the physical landscape in this region include the Rhine gorge, hilltop castles, vineyards, and picturesque valley towns. In this section is the Lorelei rock, from which a legendary siren is said to have lured fishermen to their death on the rocks. The landscape gained variety from past volcanic activity responsible for the eroded volcanic necks of the Siebengebirge (Seven Hills) near Bonn, the flooded craters and cinder cones of the Eifel Upland, and the sombre basalt flows of the Westerwald.
Where in Europe are the Schleswig-Holstein, Hamburg, and Lower Saxony Wadden Sea national parks located?

The Schleswig-Holstein, Hamburg, and Lower Saxony Wadden Sea national parks are located along the North Sea coast of Germany. The coast is broken by the estuaries of the Elbe, Weser, and Ems rivers and by drowned inlets such as the Jade and Dollart bays. Much of this area is now protected within three adjoining national parks (Schleswig-Holstein, Hamburg, and Lower Saxony Wadden Sea national parks).
What are the key features of the geographical distribution of Franconian dialects in Europe?

Franconian dialects are distributed across various regions in Europe, including parts of Germany, France, Luxembourg, and Belgium. East Franconian is spoken in northern Bavaria, South Franconian in northern Baden-Württemberg. The Rhenish Franconian dialect extends northwest from Metz, in French Lorraine, through Rhineland-Palatinate and Hessen. Moselle Franconian extends from Luxembourg through the Moselle valley districts and across the Rhine into the Westerwald.
Why has Germany's population become more widely dispersed compared to other European countries like France?
Germany's population is more widely dispersed than that of countries like France because it has historically had a profusion of states, each with its own towns and cities.
Where in Europe did land ownership significantly hinder post-unification industrial development?

Eastern Germany experienced significant barriers to establishing plants due to land ownership issues. Following the principles of the German constitution, after unification, former owners were assured that they could repossess their property or at least be compensated for their losses.
Where in Europe was Goethe's garden house and the Goethe National Museum located?
Goethe's garden house and the Goethe National Museum were located in Weimar, Germany. The Goethe House and Goethe's garden house are on the Frauenplanstrasse in Weimar.
Where is Greece located in relation to the continents of Europe, Asia, and Africa?
Greece lies at the juncture of Europe, Asia, and Africa.
What is the highest point in the Pindus mountain range in Europe?
The highest point in the Pindus mountain range is Mount Smólikas, 8,652 feet (2,637 metres) high.
Where is the Óthris mountain range continued across the Oreón Channel in Europe?
The Óthris mountain range continues across the Oreón Channel in the northern sector of the island of Évvoia.
How did the construction of the Korinthiakós Canal affect the geographical status of Pelopónnisos in southern Europe?

Pelopónnisos, also known as the Morea, is now an island, for the 3.9-mile (6.3-km) Korinthiakós Canal cuts across the narrow neck of land that formerly separated the Gulf of Korinthiakós from that of Aígina (Aíyina).
Describe the physical features of the Ionian Islands in Europe, including their terrain and climate characteristics?

The Ionian Islands are characterized by varied terrain and climate. Of the six main islands, Corfu (Modern Greek: Kérkyra), opposite the Albanian frontier, is the northernmost; it is fertile and has well-watered lowland. The other islands, Paxoí (Paxos), Lefkáda (Leucas), Itháki (Ithaca), Kefalonía (Cephallenia), and Zákynthos (Zacynthus), lie farther south and have a gaunt, broken limestone relief due to lack of rainfall, although Lefkáda and Zákynthos have sheltered eastern plains. A seventh island, Kýthira (Cythera), is grouped with the Ionian Islands for administrative purposes but is geographically discrete.
Where in Europe are black pine forests found at the highest elevations near the Mediterranean coast?
Forests and scrub are found at the highest elevations near the Mediterranean coast, near Sithonía, Greece; black pine forests cover Mount Ólympos.
What nation in Europe speaks a language unrelated to other major European languages?
Hungarians, who know their country as Magyarország, “Land of Magyrs,” are unique among the nations of Europe in that they speak a language that is not related to any other major European language.
Where are the Bakony Mountains found in Europe?
The Bakony Mountains are found in Veszprém, Hungary, in Transdanubia.
Which country in Europe had a sputtering GDP and rising unemployment?
Hungary's economy had stalled: GDP sputtered into negative growth and the unemployment rate climbed.
Where in Europe is corn commonly harvested, such as near Dunaújváros?
Corn is commonly harvested in central Hungary, such as near Dunaújváros.
What country in Eastern Europe saw a significant increase in Western-made cars on its roads between 1989 and 1996?
Hungary saw a significant increase in Western-made cars on its roads between 1989 and 1996, with an additional 1.5 million cars added.
What is Europe's largest glacier located in Iceland?
Vatna Glacier (Vatnajökull), Europe's largest glacier, is located in Iceland.
How has glacial erosion influenced the formation of natural harbours in Europe?
Glacial erosion has deepened the inner portions of the fjords, creating many fine natural harbours.
What are the key features of Europe's economy, including major sources of government revenue and employment trends, as seen in a specific country?

Iceland's economy is characterized by a significant tourist industry and a low unemployment rate. Foreign tourists number more than 300,000 a year, and the tourist industry is an important earner of foreign exchange. The central government receives a major portion of its income from a value-added tax and a progressive income tax, whereas local governments derive most of their revenue from a flat-rate income tax and property levies. With the government’s commitment to full employment, unemployment generally has remained low.
What is Ireland's location relative to Europe?
Ireland is located in western Europe, occupying five-sixths of the westernmost major island of the British Isles.
What was Ireland's economic status among Europe's regions historically?
Ireland was long among Europe's poorest regions.
What continental shelf does Ireland, part of Europe, lie on?
Ireland lies on the European continental shelf.
Why did Ireland's plant and animal life largely originate from northern Europe?

Ireland's plant and animal life largely originated from northern Europe because most species arrived overland from northern Europe as long as there was a land connection between Ireland and what was to become the rest of the British Isles.
What is Dublin considered one of in Europe?
Dublin is one of Europe’s most cosmopolitan cities.
What body of water surrounds Italy in Europe?

Italy is surrounded by the Mediterranean Sea, in particular by the Adriatic Sea to the northeast, the Ionian Sea to the southeast, the Tyrrhenian Sea to the southwest, and the Ligurian Sea to the northwest.
Which country in Europe is known for having a playwright like Luigi Pirandello?
Italy is known for having a playwright like Luigi Pirandello.
What type of wind affects the climate of Liechtenstein in Europe?
The climate of Liechtenstein is greatly affected by the warm southerly wind known as the foehn.
When was Lithuania admitted into the European Union?
Lithuania was admitted into the European Union (EU) in 2004.
Why did Luxembourg's economy develop close connections with the rest of Europe?
Luxembourg's economy developed close connections with the rest of Europe because Luxembourg itself is too small to create a self-sustaining internal market.
When was Malta admitted to the European Union?
Malta was admitted to the European Union (EU) in 2004.
Why has the soil and groundwater in Europe's Moldova region become significantly contaminated?
The excessive use of chemical fertilizers, pesticides, and herbicides during the Soviet period has resulted in significant contamination of the soil and groundwater.
What are the key features of the human geography of Europe's Moldova region in terms of ethnic composition?
